content: The "Kids First Research Act of 2013" terminates taxpayer financing of presidential election campaigns by amending the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This includes the termination of the presidential election campaign fund. The Kids First Research Act of 2013 terminates taxpayer financing of presidential election campaigns and establishes the 10-Year Pediatric Research Initiative Fund. The Kids First Research Act of 2013 establishes the 10-Year Pediatric Research Initiative Fund, which will be available for specific purposes outlined in the Public Health Service Act. Any unobligated funds in the account will be deposited into the Treasury's general fund by October 1, 2024. The provisions of this chapter do not apply to any candidate in presidential elections after the enactment of this section. Clerical amendments are made to update the table of sections in the Code. The Public Health Service Act is amended to allocate NIH funds for pediatric research through the Division of Program Coordination, Planning, and Strategic Initiatives. This includes identifying important research areas, collaborating between national research institutes, and strategic planning. The Public Health Service Act is amended to allocate NIH funds for pediatric research through the Division of Program Coordination, Planning, and Strategic Initiatives. This includes setting milestones, timeframes, and considering new principal investigators for research proposals funded by the National Institutes of Health. Funds reserved for the Common Fund can be allocated accordingly. The Public Health Service Act is amended to allocate NIH funds for pediatric research through the Division of Program Coordination, Planning, and Strategic Initiatives. This includes setting milestones, timeframes, and considering new principal investigators for research proposals funded by the National Institutes of Health. Funds reserved for the Common Fund can be allocated to national research institutes and centers for conducting and supporting research, as well as making grants for pediatric research. Additional functions may be assigned to the Division as determined appropriate by the Director. The Public Health Service Act is amended to allocate NIH funds for pediatric research through the Division of Program Coordination, Planning, and Strategic Initiatives. This includes setting milestones, timeframes, and considering new principal investigators for research proposals funded by the National Institutes of Health. Funds reserved for the Common Fund can be allocated to national research institutes and centers for conducting and supporting research, as well as making grants for pediatric research. Additionally, there is authorization for funding a 10-year pediatric research initiative through the Common Fund. Funds allocated under section 402A(a)(2) of the Public Health Service Act must supplement, not replace, existing NIH funds for pediatric research. These funds are designated for making grants as outlined in section 402(b)(7)(B)(ii) and cannot be transferred for other purposes. SEC. 4. PROHIBITION AGAINST NIH RESEARCH ON HEALTH ECONOMICS. Section 402A of the Public Health Service Act is amended to require the Director of NIH to justify ongoing health economics research projects before continuing them, prioritizing research on pediatric diseases without cures. New health economics research projects cannot be initiated until a report is submitted. The Director of NIH must justify current health economics research projects and prioritize pediatric diseases without cures. New projects cannot start until a report is submitted and a law authorizing funding for health economics research is enacted.
